title: Nationals on ropes after another home World Series loss in Game 5
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: This may be the most energetic World Series we've seen in a long time. For both teams, their exuberance on and off the field has been propelled by the joy often seen in Latin baseball culture. USA TODAY

WASHINGTON -- The Washington Nationals were quietly making plans for a parade route, ordering the perfect vintage champagne, and making sure all of the nation’s finest dignitaries were on hand for the historic moment.

Really, they thought they planned for everything.

Well, someone forgot the memo to bring along the bats from Houston.

The Houston Astros shut down the Nats’ offense for the third consecutive game Sunday night, winning 7-1, and now are just one victory away from their second World Series championship in three years.

The Nats, after scoring 17 runs in their first two victories at Houston, were limited to just one for the third consecutive game, and now trail 3 games to 2 as the World Series returns to Houston.

The game will be remembered for the jarring text message that starter Max Scherzer sent to Nats GM Mike Rizzo and trainer Paul Lessard at 11:30 in the morning, letting them know he was in excruciating pain from neck and back spasms, and couldn’t pitch.

Nationals starting pitcher Joe Ross gave up four runs on two homers in Game 5. (Photo: Brad Mills, USA TODAY Sports)

“When I woke up this morning I was completely locked up,’’ Scherzer said. “It became impossible just to do any menial task whatsoever today. I couldn't get out of bed. I had to just basically fall out of bed. Just couldn't even move my arm. I just knew at that point I was in a really bad spot.

“I've pitched through so much crap in my career that that would be easy to pitch through at this point. This is literally impossible to do anything with.

“This is just a little thing that turned into a big thing that turned into a giant thing.’’

Despite the terrible news, the Nats still believed they were going to win this game, with Rizzo telling everyone that would listen it would only be the latest chapter to this storied season.

“When we got the news this morning,’’ Rizzo said, “it was, 'Ok, the first pitch is going to be at 8:07, whether we have Max Scherzer or not. What are you going to do?

“I wish it was Scherzer, (Stephen) Strasburg and (Anibal) Sanchez, but it’s not. We got to present a united front. This is we, instead of a me type-of-thing. This is us against the world. That’s what we got.

“But I also said, 'You need to get more than four hits and one run to win any of these damn games.’’’

Well, by the end of the night, they got four hits and one run.

Yet again.

The loss certainly can’t be blamed on emergency starter Joe Ross, who kept them in the game for five innings, but they could have called on Walter Johnson, and it wouldn’t matter.

If the Nats can’t push runs across the plate, what difference does it make who’s pitching for them?

Astros co-ace Gerrit Cole didn’t give them a chance, giving up just three hits, and not surrendering his first run until Juan Soto’s seventh-inning home run.

The Nats will have Strasburg go in Game 6 going against AL Cy Young favorite Justin Verlander, but they better find some offense in a hurry to keep their season alive.

“Everybody says you’re playing with house money,’’ Rizzo said. “Bull ... We want to win the World Series.

“We put this team together not to win the wild card, or the division series, but to win the World Series.

“This is the kind of season that you write a book about.’’

This is a team that lost Bryce Harper to free agency in the offseason.

A team that was buried back in May with a 19-31 record.

GAME 5: Max Scherzer scratched from start

HELLO: Trump booed at Game 5 of World Series

It’s a team that was four outs away from being eliminated in the wild-card game.

A team that was six outs from going home in the NL Division Series.

They aren’t about to let an injury stop them now.

“I think we’re every bit as good as that team,’’ Rizzo said, gesturing towards the Astros’ bench. “I thought we were every bit as good as the Dodgers. These are super teams, and I think we can play with all of them.’’

Well, they better learn how to hit with them.

The Astros outscored the Nats’ 19-3 in the three games at Nationals Park, with a trio of two-run homers, courtesy of Jordan Alvarez, Carlos Correa and George Springer.

“It’s what we’ve dealt with all year,’’ Nats outfielder Adam Eaton said, “getting punched in the face and coming back.

“Sometimes you need to get punched in the face in order to get back in the fight.’’

Well, they better hurry, because this fight is about to end.

Follow Nightengale on Twitter @Bnightengale
description: After losing the first two games of the World Series, the Astros have won the last three and are now on the brink of a World Series title.
